newsitem.title: BULGARIA: Bulgarians go to polls, reformists expect victory.
newsitem.headline: Bulgarians go to polls, reformists expect victory.

text.p: Bulgarians vote on Saturday in elections expected to launch them down the path of economic reform taken by most of their east European neighbours years ago.

The results of the parliamentary elections are largely a foregone conclusion. The biggest question is how big an absolute majority will be won by reformists who led a winter of unrest which forced the ruling ex-communists to call the polls two years early.

Two opinion polls on Friday gave the Union of Democratic Forces (UDF) 47 and 56 percent support, easily enough to secure a clear majority in the 240-seat parliament, and the ex-communist Socialists between 19 and 24 percent. UDF leader Ivan Kostov is expected to become the new prime minister.

For the first time since the fall of communist dictatorship in 1989, the incoming government should enjoy clear support for market reforms of the still state-dominated economy from across the political spectrum -- even from the Socialists, long blamed for obstructing change.

A $1.2 billion credit package from international lenders is conditional on the introduction of strict monetary controls and mass privatisation, a painful cure for economic collapse. Under an interim government formed in February, the first steps have already been taken.
Previous governments over the past seven years have paid lip service to change but reforms have remained mainly on the drawing board, held up by political wrangling.

The Socialists, who won 1994 elections, stand accused of economic mismanagement that has fuelled inflation of more than 2,000 percent a year. But they still command loyalty among many old people who lived most of their lives under communist rule.
Support for the UDF, in contrast, is concentrated among the under-40s.

Among three smaller coalitions likely to break the threshold of four percent support needed to win a place in parliament are monarchists who want the return of exiled King Simeon, representatives of Bulgaria's ethnic Turkish minority, and defectors from the Socialists.
A total of 4,448 candidates are standing in the polls. Under a proportional representation system, parties and coalitions put up lists of candidates in each of 31 electoral districts.
Polling stations open at 6 a.m. (0300 GMT) and close at 7 p.m. (1600 GMT) and first results are expected on Saturday evening.
The election has failed to ignite the passions of a demoralised public who in January and February besieged the Socialist-dominated parliament and took to the streets to demand early elections.
Bulgarian newspapers said on Friday they expected a turnout of some 70-75 percent, compared with 61 percent in the final round of presidential polls in November.
Some 72 percent say, however, they have not bothered to read the rival parties' election campaign programmes, according to Bulgarian pollsters Sova-5. REUTER 182212 GMT apr 97
